encodingDesc.p: Transcriptions are encoded in TEI(P5)-conformant XML.

correction.p: Apparent errors are preserved and editorial corrections provided using SIC and CORR tags, but only where the editor conjectures that the original scribe or compositor would have recognized the instance as an error. For example, what according to modern usage is incorrect subject/verb agreement might have been deemed acceptable to a seventeenth-century scribe or compositor. All such instances are treated instead using the ORIG and REG tags. (See below.)

Corrections and annotations made within the scope of the original document either by its original authors, owners, and/or transcribers are noted using ADD tags. These annotations and may be futher explained within NOTE tags, as added by the editors of this digital edition, for display within the apparatus.

normalization.p: Original spellings, abbreviations, and orthography are preserved. Where in the manuscripts a character's status as majuscule or miniscule is ambiguous, the editor has silently chosen one or the other based on context and judgment (i.e., does not register such ambiguity in either the markup or the notes).

quotation.p: Original quotation marks, if any, are preserved.

glyph.glyphName: Handwritten 'ff' ligature, used in handwriting to represent modern F

listWit.witness: Transcription of manuscript: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.
Elemental edition: By Leah Knight and Wendy Wall.

app.rdg: PG#[Emblem 43]

This Stately Ship
(Emblem 43)
AE TITLE

rdg.note: In these transcriptions we preserve as many details of the original material, textual, and graphic properties of Hester Pulter’s manuscript verse as we have found practical. Whenever possible, for instance, original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, lineation, insertions, deletions, alterations, spacing between words and lines, and indentation are all maintained; abbreviations and brevigraphs are not expanded; and superscript and subscript representations are retained. See full conventions for the transcriptions here.

The aim of the elemental edition is to make the poems accessible to the largest variety of readers, which involves modernizing spelling and punctuation as well as adding basic glosses. Spelling and punctuation reflect current standard American usage; punctuation highlights syntax which might otherwise be obscure. Outmoded but still familiar word forms (“thou,” “‘tis,” “hold’st”) are not modernized, and we do not modernize grammar when the sense remains legible. After a brief headnote aimed at offering a “way in” to the poem’s unique qualities and connections with other verse by Pulter or her contemporaries, the edition features a minimum of notes and interpretative framing to allow more immediate engagement with the poem. Glosses clarify synonyms or showcase various possible meanings in Pulter’s time. Other notes identify named people and places or clarify obscure material. We rely (without citation) primarily on the Oxford English Dictionary (OED), the Oxford Reference database, and the King James Version (KJV) of the Bible. When we rely on Alice Eardley’s edition of Pulter’s work, we cite her text generally (“Eardley”); other sources are cited in full. The result is an edition we consider a springboard for further work on Pulter’s poetry. See full conventions for this edition here.

By offering examples of how diminutive and seemingly insignificant things (flies, worms, clothes) can overcome even the mightiest people, this emblem warns against the vanity of human overconfidence and pride (vices that Pulter sees in the tyrannies of English politics of the day). The central conceit is of a magisterial ship able to battle and survive the worst ocean storms; Pulter develops this conventional metaphor of the ship of state by asking the reader to imaginatively fuse two stories of sailors battling the elements: Aeneas, in conflict with the goddess Juno when fleeing Troy, and King James VI of Scotland (later James I of England), who believed witches tried to wreck him and his queen at sea as an attack on royal power. As it turns out, small suckerfish–invisibly glued to the keel of a boat–could accomplish what powerful tempests at sea could not: halt the ship in its tracks. The poem’s central image of an anchored ship morphs at this point in the poem into numerous sailing vessels from Roman and Greek histories, all of which succumbed to the unexpected power of a something lower down on the food chain.

app.rdg: Thisfirst third of page occupied by end of previous poem; second third blank Stately Ship Courted by Winds & Tide
This stately ship, courted by winds and tide,
Upon the Curling Billows Swiftly Rides
Upon the curling billows swiftly rides,
Proud of her Carri’dg nothing Shee did fear
Proud of her carriage; nothing she did fear,
&ff;or Cæſar and his &ff;ortunes Shee did bear

For Caesar and his fortunes she did bearThe first eight lines of this poem describe how Aeneas sought to sail away from the defeated city of Troy after the Trojan war. Virgil (at the opening of in his Aeneid) narrates how the goddess Juno disrupted Aeneas’s voyage by means of storms created by Aeolus (the wind god), before Neptune (god of the ocean and sympathetic to Aeneas as the son of his niece, Venus) intervened. The Roman Emperor Julius Caesar traced his lineage to Ascanius, son of Aeneas..
Great Neptune for his lovly Neeces ſake
Great Neptune, for his lovely niece’s sake,
Did Charg old Eolus a peace to make
Did charge old Aeolus a peace to make
Between thoſe bluſtring Tetarks, all Jarrs
Between those blust’ring tetrarchsfour joint rulers; here, the winds from the four cardinal directions, all jarsdiscords, disputes
Which &ff;ills his Trembling Kingdoms w:th ſuch Wars
WhichOf which fills his trembling kingdoms with such wars.
The Halcion too her Young had new diſcloſ’d
The halcyona mythical bird, formerly a daughter of Aelous, who would calm the seas when the halcyon brooded over her nest at sea; also, the kingfisher bird, too, her young had new disclosed,
And all but one Trade Wind were now Repoſ’d
And all but one trade windsteady unidirectional wind, especially at sea were now reposedat rest; tranquil.
I verily think Some Elfin Lapland Hags

I verily think some elfin Lapland hagsFolklore had it that witches (“hags”) from the region of Finland would sell wind to mariners. See James George Frazier, The Golden Bough: A Study in Magic and Religion, (New York: Macmillan, 1923), vol. 1, p. 81.
Had put the one and Thirty Winds in Bags
Had put the one-and-thirty winds in bags,
As when the Learned’st of great &ff;ergus Seed

As when the learned’st of great Fergus’s seedJames VI of Scotland, who became James I of England, claimed descent from Fergus, the first king of Scotland. In this and the lines that follow, Pulter alludes to the fact that when James I travelled back to Scotland (emblemized by the River Tweed) from Denmark with his bride, Anne (here called an “elf”), they encountered storms that James attributed to the devices of witchcraft. In Scottish witchcraft trials in the 1590s, some women were charged with attempting to destroy the monarchy by sinking his ship.
Did fetch the Elve, to Marry w:th his Tweed
Did fetch the elf to marry with his Tweed.
They Gave the King old Borus in A Purſs

They gave the king old Borus in a purseBoreas was the name given by the Greeks to the north wind. Here Pulter might be alluding to the fact that Ulysses received the winds in a leather bag from Aeolus, the wind god; but she fuses it into the story of the Northern witches who reputedly caused King James of Scotland’s ships to go awry.;
I wiſh noe Witches ever may doe Worſs
I wish no witches ever may do worse.
And thus this Gallant Ship did make her Way
And thus this gallantnoble, stately ship did make her way
When too their Strang Amazement Shee did Stay
When, to their strange amazement, she did stayhalt; remain fixed.
Some &ff;url’dblot over “l” the Sayls and others tri’de ye Oar
Some furled the sails, and others tried the oar;
A Thouſand other Tricks they did explore
A thousand other tricks they did explore.
Noe Shelf, nor Sand, nor dangerous Rock was near
No shelfa sandbank in the sea rendering the water shallow and dangerous, nor sand, nor dangerous rock was near,
Which made them Some Infernall mallesmalicedirectly above malles fear
Which made them some infernal malice fear.
At lcrossed out with three slanted lines last great Julius made one Dive and feel

At last, great JuliusJulius Caesar. Pulter puts Julius Caesar into a story that her source (Pliny) attributed to other Roman leaders (Mark Antony and Roman Emperor Caius, or Caligula). See Pliny, The History of The World, trans. Philemon Holland (London, 1634), Book 32, Ch. 1: pp. 425-26. made one dive and feel,
Who found a Remora Stick on ye Keell

Whoand found a remora(Latin for “delay); a fish with a sucker for attaching to the undersides of sea creatures or ships, also called an Echeneis. Numerous emblem books and literary texts of the day described ships delayed or halted by small sea creatures. See E. W. Gudger, “Some Old Time Figures of the Shipholder, Echeneis or Remora, Holding the Ship,” Isis (1930),13:2, pp. 340-52. stick on the keel.
Theſein left margin: “*Plinie 9th Book / Chap: 2d fol: 249” Staid the Ship if *Plinie Tels the truth

These stayed the ship, if Pliny tells the truthIn the margin left of this line, a note refers readers to Pliny’s ninth book, chapter 2, folio 249; Chapter 25 (rather than Chapter 2) of the ninth book of Philemon Holland’s translation of Pliny’s natural history states that fish called echeneis (or “stay-ships”) “chanced upon a time to cleave fast unto a ship, bringing messengers from Periander, with commission to geld all the noblemen’s sons in Gnidos, and stayed it a long time.” Pliny, The History of the World, trans. Philemon Holland (London, 1634), p. 249.,
When Periander Sent to Geld the Youth
When Periander sent to geld the youthPeriander, an ancient tyrant in Corinth, had three hundred sons of his enemies castrated as punishment for their killing of his son.
Of Gnidos“n” written over other letter, I wiſh Some &ff;ind^Fiendtriple strike-through; subscript caret below “nd" may Stay
Of Knidosa Greek city in Asia Minor, in modern Turkey; “Gnidos” in the manuscript. I wish some fiend may stay
Thoſe Ships which ſuch proud Tyrants doe obey
Those ships which such proud tyrants do obey;
But if A Starr ſhould Shoot whilst I wiſh Soe
But if a star should shoot whilst I wish soA common superstition was that a wish made on a shooting star would come true.,
&ff;ew Ships from Brittiſh Harbours then would goe
Few ships from British harbors then would go.
By this wee See how poor A thing will Stop
By this we see how poor a thing will stop
Mans prowd deſigns twas Mordicaifinal “i” appears written over an earlier “s” Stiff knee

Man’s proud designs. ’Twas Mordecai’s stiff kneeIn the biblical Book of Esther, the Jewish Mordecai is the cousin of Queen Esther. His refusal to bow to Haman, the king’s chief advisor, leads Haman to plan a massacre of the Jews and Mordecai’s hanging; Haman, however, winds up hanged on the gallows he built for Mordecai.
That trust up Hamon on the &ff;atall Tree
That trussed up Haman on the fatal tree;
A worm abrupted great Agryppas Glory
A worm abrupted great Agrippa’s gloryHerod Agrippa I “was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost” because “he gave not God the glory” (Acts 12:23).;
A &ff;ly did End Popeimperfectly erased line after “e” Alexanders Story

A fly did end Pope Alexander’s storyLegend had it that the twelfth century Pope Adrian IV died because he drank water with a fly in it and choked. Pulter resituates this incident as happening to one of the popes named Alexander.;
Soe &ff;air Cr^eueſainserted “e” in different hand and ink; original “e” blotted out in her height of Pride
So fair CreusaThe second wife of Jason, whose first wife, Medea, douses Creusa’s garment (the “mantle” of the next line) with a flammable liquid which burns Creusa to death., in her height of pride,
By an inflamable Rich Mantle died
By an inflammable rich mantle died.
Then let us all move humble in our Spheer“p” shows erased ascender (as for “h”); final two letters scribbled out Spherein different hand from main scribe
Then let us all move humble in our sphere,
And then noe“e” scribbled over Remora wee need to &ff;ear.
And then no remora we need to fear.
